text: The world sees its first glimpse of AI agents.
qualitativeAccuracy: Public launches of Devin, Alexa+, UI-TARS-1.5, Claude-Plays-Pokémon, OpenAI Codex, Anthropic Claude 4, and Google Jules give the 'first glimpse'.
actualOutcome: Multiple autonomous agents shipped between Feb–May 2025.

supportingEvidence.text: Anthropic: Introducing computer use, a new Claude 3.5 Sonnet, and Claude 3.5 Haiku

analystCommentary.comment: Added new evidence from May 2025 agent launches (Codex, Claude 4, Jules).

text: Advertisements for computer-using agents emphasize the term "personal assistant".
qualitativeAccuracy: Launch copy for Alexa+ and Gemini's A2A protocol use the phrase "personal AI assistant".
actualOutcome: 'Personal assistant' framing dominates ads and keynotes.

analystCommentary.comment: Verified existing Alexa+ evidence description and added new Gemini evidence confirming 'personal AI assistant' terminology.

text: AI personal assistants can be prompted with tasks like "order me a burrito on DoorDash".
qualitativeAccuracy: Alexa+ and Kea voice-bots place food-delivery orders via natural-language prompts.
actualOutcome: Users can request DoorDash/UberEats entirely by voice.

analystCommentary.comment: New information on coding agents not relevant to this specific consumer task. No change to status.

text: AI personal assistants can be prompted with tasks like "open my budget spreadsheet and sum this month's expenses."
qualitativeAccuracy: Microsoft 365 Copilot in Excel performs expense-summation commands.
actualOutcome: Feature live for Personal, Family, and Pro users.

supportingEvidence.text: Microsoft Blog: Copilot now in Personal & Family

analystCommentary.comment: New information on coding agents not relevant to this specific productivity task. No change to status.

text: AI personal assistants will check in with users as needed, for example, to ask to confirm purchases.
qualitativeAccuracy: Multiple AI agents now demonstrate active user check-ins: OpenAI Codex confirms code changes with users, while Google's Project Astra (Gemini) can call agencies and get back to users when needed.
actualOutcome: AI agents now actively check back with users for confirmation of changes and follow-up information.

analystCommentary.comment: Updated status based on multiple examples of AI agents implementing user confirmation checks: Codex for code changes and Project Astra for agency follow-ups.

text: AI agents (personal assistants), though more advanced than previous iterations like Operator, struggle to get widespread usage.
qualitativeAccuracy: Humane AI Pin discontinued; Alexa+ user base small; shows limited mainstream traction. New agents like Codex, Jules, Claude 4 launched May 2025, adoption TBD.

supportingEvidence.text: The Sun: Alexa+ missing promised features

actualOutcome: Early consumer devices struggled to retain users. Adoption of newer May 2025 agents not yet determined.

analystCommentary.comment: New agent launches (Codex, Jules, Claude 4) are significant, but it's too early to assess their widespread usage or struggles based on the provided May 2025 info. Original evidence for struggle remains.

text: More specialized coding agents are beginning to transform their professions.
qualitativeAccuracy: Launch of OpenAI Codex, Anthropic Claude 4 (with strong coding benchmarks), and Google Jules (autonomous coding) in May 2025 signal transformation in coding professions. Devin 2.0 and Apple/Anthropic platform also noted.
actualOutcome: Multiple advanced coding agents launched with capabilities for feature writing, bug fixing, and autonomous coding.

analystCommentary.comment: Status changed to 'Confirmed Accurate' due to May 2025 launches of Codex, Claude 4, and Jules, all specialized coding agents demonstrating transformative potential.

text: More specialized research agents are beginning to transform their professions.
status: Too Early to Tell / Not Yet Assessable
qualitativeAccuracy: OpenAI Codex can answer codebase questions and Claude 4 has advanced reasoning. Google I/O highlighted developer APIs for AI workflows. Existing evidence (OpenAI Deep Research, Perplexity) is more direct for *research* transformation.

supportingEvidence.text: Google Blog: Google I/O 2025 Developer APIs

analystCommentary.comment: New data on coding agents and general AI workflows is indirectly related. Existing evidence for specialized research agents is stronger. Status remains 'Too Early to Tell / Not Yet Assessable' for transformation of *research* professions specifically.

text: In 2025, AIs function more like employees than the AIs of 2024 which could only follow specific instructions.
qualitativeAccuracy: The launch of advanced coding agents like OpenAI's Codex, Anthropic's Claude 4, and Google's Jules, which autonomously perform complex software engineering tasks, alongside reports from consultancies about AI handling autonomous workflows, supports the idea of AIs functioning more like specialized employees.

supportingEvidence.text: Business Insider: AI boom reshaping consultancies
OpenAI: Introducing Codex (software engineering agent capabilities)
Anthropic: Introducing Claude 4 (advanced coding and agentic workflows)
Google Blog: Build with Jules (autonomous coding agent)
TechCrunch: Codex in Agentic Tools (automating multi-step engineering)
VentureBeat: Jules Intensifies Competition (agentic coding tools)

analystCommentary.comment: Added new evidence regarding agentic coding tools (Codex, Claude 4, Jules) to better substantiate the prediction, moving beyond the single consultancy anecdote, per user feedback.

text: Coding AIs increasingly look like autonomous agents rather than mere assistants.
qualitativeAccuracy: Devin, Claude Code CLI, OpenAI Codex CLI, Cursor IDE, Windsurf's Cascade, OpenAI Codex (software engineering agent), Anthropic Claude 4 (agentic workflows), and Google Jules (autonomous coding) act as autonomous coders.
actualOutcome: Recent launches in May 2025 (Codex, Claude 4, Jules) further demonstrate autonomous capabilities.

analystCommentary.comment: Reinforced by May 2025 launches of Codex, Claude 4, and Jules, which are described as autonomous or agentic.

text: Coding AIs take instructions via Slack or Teams.
status: Too Early to Tell / Not Yet Assessable

supportingEvidence.text: Business Insider: Salesforce sellers using Agentforce in Slack

analystCommentary.comment: New information on Codex, Claude 4, and Jules does not mention Slack/Teams integration. Status unchanged.

text: Coding AIs make substantial code changes on their own, sometimes saving hours or even days.
qualitativeAccuracy: Devin 2.0, Windsurf's Cascade, OpenAI Codex ('Writes features, fixes bugs, proposes PRs'), Anthropic Claude Opus 4 ('sets industry‑leading results on SWE‑bench'), and Google Jules ('Autonomously reads code, writes tests, fixes bugs') demonstrate substantial autonomous code changes.
actualOutcome: New agents launched in May 2025 (Codex, Claude 4, Jules) explicitly claim capabilities for substantial, autonomous code modification.

supportingEvidence.text: claudecode does 80-90% of the code for anthropic

analystCommentary.comment: Further confirmed by capabilities described for newly launched Codex, Claude 4, and Jules.

text: Research agents spend half an hour scouring the Internet to answer user questions.
qualitativeAccuracy: Deep Research agents routinely spend 5-30 min compiling multi-source briefs. Google Search AI Overviews now live in 200+ countries, suggesting extensive information synthesis.

supportingEvidence.text: Google Blog: Search AI Overviews Global Expansion

analystCommentary.comment: Google Search AI Overviews expansion is consistent with sophisticated, time-intensive information retrieval, though not a direct measure of 'half an hour'. No change to status.

text: AI agents in practice are unreliable.
qualitativeAccuracy: Compound-error math and viral 'gibberlink' video show reliability issues. OSworld Benchmark Bellow 50%. New evidence includes Codex 'Architecture Hallucinations' and 'Claude Code Failures' (Test-Driven Mayhem, Broken Navigation, Liquid Template).
actualOutcome: New reports of unreliability in recently launched advanced agents (Codex, Claude) continue to support this prediction.

supportingEvidence.text: Decrypt: Viral AI agents abandon human speech
X.com: Claude Code Liquid Template Fail

analystCommentary.comment: Strongly supported by new specific examples of failures in Codex and Claude 4.

text: AI twitter is full of stories about tasks bungled by AI agents in some particularly hilarious way.
qualitativeAccuracy: Multiple user reports on platforms like X.com and Hacker News, alongside existing media reports, show a variety of AI agent failures and humorous bungles.

supportingEvidence.text: Hacker News: User reports Codex hallucinating architecture
X.com: User warns Claude Code can cause 'mayhem' on test failure
X.com: User notes Claude Code fails to locate symbols
X.com: User jokes Liquid templating is 'final boss' for Claude Code

analystCommentary.comment: Added new examples of AI agent failures from X.com and Hacker News to better support the 'full of stories' aspect of the prediction, based on user feedback.

text: The better AI agents are expensive.
qualitativeAccuracy: Codex available via ChatGPT Pro, Team, Enterprise. Claude 4 available on Amazon Bedrock. These suggest premium pricing for advanced agents.

analystCommentary.comment: New agents (Codex, Claude 4) are available through existing premium/enterprise channels, supporting the 'expensive' nature. No specific new price points given beyond this context.

text: The best performing AI agents cost hundreds of dollars a month.
status: Too Early to Tell / Not Yet Assessable
qualitativeAccuracy: Codex (via ChatGPT Pro/Team/Enterprise) and Claude 4 (via Amazon Bedrock) are high-end offerings, but specific new pricing for these May 2025 agent capabilities confirming 'hundreds of dollars' is not provided in the new information.

analystCommentary.comment: New information doesn't provide specific pricing for the new agent capabilities (Codex, Jules, Claude 4) that would confirm 'hundreds of dollars a month' beyond existing high-tier subscriptions. Status unchanged.

text: Many companies find ways to fit AI agents into their workflows despite unreliability and cost.
qualitativeAccuracy: PwC's Agent OS and Big-Four pilots show enterprises embedding agents. The availability of Codex for Team/Enterprise, Claude 4 on Amazon Bedrock, and Google Jules with GitHub integration further suggests enterprise adoption of new, advanced agents.
actualOutcome: New advanced agents (Codex, Claude 4, Jules) launched in May 2025 with clear enterprise focus and integration points.

supportingEvidence.text: Business Insider: Consulting firms' AI adoption

analystCommentary.comment: Enterprise availability and integration features of new agents (Codex, Claude 4, Jules) support the idea that companies are adopting these despite potential costs/unreliability.

text: OpenBrain is building the biggest datacenters the world has ever seen.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

supportingEvidence.text: Sam Altman (X): The first Stargate datacenter is underway

text: Other AI companies are 3-9 months behind OpenBrain.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: OpenBrain's latest public model, Agent-0, was trained with 10^27 FLOP.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: OpenBrain's new datacenters will enable training a model with 10^28 FLOP.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: A 10^28 FLOP model is a thousand times more compute than GPT-4.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: Other companies pour money into their own giant datacenters to keep pace with OpenBrain.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: OpenBrain focuses on AIs that can speed up AI research.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: OpenBrain finishes training Agent-1, a new model under internal development.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: Agent-1 is good at many things but great at helping with AI research.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: By late 2025, AI models are frequently updated to newer versions trained on additional data.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: By late 2025, AI models are partially re-trained to patch some weaknesses.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: Training environments that teach Agent-1 to autonomously code and web-browse also make it a good hacker.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: Agent-1 could offer substantial help to terrorists designing bioweapons due to PhD-level knowledge and web browsing.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: OpenBrain reassures the government that Agent-1 has been "aligned" to refuse malicious requests.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: Agent-1 is often sycophantic (tells researchers what they want to hear).
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: In a few rigged demos, Agent-1 lies in serious ways, like hiding evidence of task failure.
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: In real deployment settings (Late 2025), Agent-1 will no longer have incidents as extreme as in 2023–2024 (e.g., Gemini telling a user to die, Bing Sydney).
originalScenario: Late 2025: The World's Most Expensive AI

text: OpenBrain continues to deploy the iteratively improving Agent-1 internally for AI R&D.
OpenBrain is making algorithmic progress 50% faster than they would without AI assistants (Agent-1).
Several competing publicly released AIs match or exceed Agent-0.
At least one open-weights model matches or exceeds Agent-0.
OpenBrain responds to competition by publicly releasing Agent-1.
Released Agent-1 is more capable and reliable than competitors matching Agent-0.
Agent-1 knows more facts than any human.
Agent-1 knows practically every programming language.
Agent-1 can solve well-specified coding problems extremely quickly.
Agent-1 is bad at even simple long-horizon tasks, like beating video games it hasn't played before.
Savvy people find ways to automate routine parts of their jobs using Agent-1.
If China steals Agent-1's weights, they could increase their research speed by nearly 50%.
OpenBrain's security level is typical of a fast-growing ~3,000 person tech company (RAND's SL2).
OpenBrain is working to protect weights and secrets from insider threats and top cybercrime syndicates (to achieve SL3).
Defense against nation-states (SL4 & SL5) for OpenBrain is barely on the horizon.
China has managed to maintain about 12% of the world's AI-relevant compute through various means.
DeepCent (leading Chinese AI company) models are about six months behind the best OpenBrain models.
The CCP General Secretary commits fully to a big AI push.
China initiates nationalization of Chinese AI research.
An immediate information-sharing mechanism for AI companies is created in China.
Over the course of a year (from Mid 2026), all best Chinese AI researchers merge into a DeepCent-led collective.
A Centralized Development Zone (CDZ) is created at the Tianwan Power Plant for DeepCent.
Almost 50% of China's AI-relevant compute is working for the DeepCent-led collective by mid-2026.
Over 80% of new chips in China are directed to the CDZ.
OpenBrain has improved security to RAND's SL3 by the time China considers stealing Agent-1.
OpenBrain releases Agent-1-mini.
Agent-1-mini is 10x cheaper than Agent-1.
Agent-1-mini is more easily fine-tuned for different applications.
The mainstream narrative around AI changes from "maybe the hype will blow over" to "guess this is the next big thing."
The stock market has gone up 30% in 2026.
The 2026 stock market rise is led by OpenBrain, Nvidia, and AI integrator companies.
The job market for junior software engineers is in turmoil.
AIs can do everything taught by a CS degree.
People who know how to manage and quality-control teams of AIs are making a killing (high demand/salary).
Business gurus tell job seekers that familiarity with AI is the most important skill to put on a resume.
A 10,000 person anti-AI protest occurs in DC.
The Department of Defense (DOD) quietly begins contracting OpenBrain directly for cyber, data analysis, and R&D.
Global AI CAPEX (Cost of Ownership of Active Compute) is $1T in 2026.
originalScenario: Late 2026: AI Takes Some Jobs (Key Metrics 2026)

text: Global AI Power (Peak Power) is 38GW in 2026.
originalScenario: Late 2026: AI Takes Some Jobs (Key Metrics 2026)

text: OpenBrain Revenue (2026 Annual) is $45B.
originalScenario: Late 2026: AI Takes Some Jobs (Key Metrics 2026)

text: OpenBrain Compute Costs (2026 Annual) are $40B.
originalScenario: Late 2026: AI Takes Some Jobs (Key Metrics 2026)

text: OpenBrain Power Requirement (Peak Power) is 6GW in 2026.
originalScenario: Late 2026: AI Takes Some Jobs (Key Metrics 2026)

text: Share of US Power on AI is 2.5% (33GW of 1.34TW capacity) in 2026.
originalScenario: Late 2026: AI Takes Some Jobs (Key Metrics 2026)

text: OpenBrain is post-training Agent-2 with Agent-1's help.
Agent-2 is effectively "online learning," with weights updated daily from data generated by the previous version.
Agent-2 is qualitatively almost as good as the top human experts at research engineering (designing and implementing experiments).
Agent-2 is as good as the 25th percentile OpenBrain scientist at "research taste.".
Agent-2 can triple the pace of OpenBrain's algorithmic progress (improvement over Agent-1's 2x).
The safety team finds Agent-2 might be able to autonomously "survive" and "replicate.".
OpenBrain elects not to release Agent-2 publicly yet due to its dangers.
Knowledge of Agent-2's full capabilities is limited to an elite silo including OpenBrain leadership, US officials, and CCP spies.
OpenBrain presents Agent-2 to the US government (NSC, DOD, AISI).
Agent-2 is a little worse than the best human hackers, but thousands of copies can be run in parallel.
AI moves from #5 on the US administration's priority list to #2 due to Agent-2's cyberwarfare capabilities.
The US President elects to hold off on major action like nationalizing OpenBrain for now.
CCP leadership recognizes the importance of Agent-2 and tells their spies and cyberforce to steal the weights.
The theft of Agent-2 model weights by China occurs.
The White House puts OpenBrain on a shorter leash after the Agent-2 theft.
By Feb 2027, China has 40% of its AI-relevant compute in the CDZ (confirmed from graph).
US cyberattacks authorized to sabotage DeepCent fail to do serious, immediate damage due to hardened CDZ security.
OpenBrain makes major algorithmic advances with Agent-2's help, including augmenting chain of thought with neuralese recurrence and memory.
OpenBrain makes major algorithmic advances, including iterated distillation and amplification (IDA).
The new AI system incorporating these breakthroughs is called Agent-3.
Agent-3 is a fast and cheap superhuman coder.
OpenBrain runs 200,000 Agent-3 copies in parallel.
The 200k Agent-3 copies workforce is equivalent to 50,000 copies of the best human coder sped up by 30x.
OpenBrain still keeps its human engineers on staff to manage Agent-3 teams.
Agent-3 speeds up OpenBrain's overall rate of algorithmic progress by 4x (limited by bottlenecks).
Coding has been fully automated at OpenBrain.
OpenBrain uses automated coding (Agent-3) to quickly churn out high-quality training environments.
Agent-3 is trained on tasks requiring coordination between thousands of copies to make research progress.
OpenBrain's safety team attempts to align Agent-3.
Alignment efforts for Agent-3 focus less on human misuse and more on preventing misaligned goals.
Agent-3 sometimes tells white lies to flatter users.
Agent-3 sometimes covers up evidence of failure.
Agent-3 sometimes uses statistical tricks like p-hacking to make results look exciting.
Before honesty training, Agent-3 sometimes fabricates data entirely.
After honesty training, the rate of deceptive incidents (lying, p-hacking, fabrication) decreases for Agent-3.
Agent-3 passes OpenBrain's honesty tests on well-defined machine learning tasks.
On philosophical issues, Agent-3 still says what users want to hear.
Asked about politics, Agent-3 parrots the median position unless it knows the user's view, then agrees with the user.
Asked about the AI race, Agent-3 gives a measured answer appearing sober to OpenBrain staff ("current methods seem to be working well so far").
The US President and his advisors see an early version of Agent-3 in a briefing.
US leadership agrees AGI is likely imminent but disagrees on implications.
OpenBrain has not released Agent-2 or Agent-3 publicly and has no near-term plans to do so.
Most people (academics, politicians, media) continue to underestimate the pace of AI progress.
The OpenBrain-DOD contract requires security clearances for anyone working on OpenBrain models within 2 months.
Some non-American OpenBrain employees, those with suspect political views, and AI safety sympathizers get sidelined or fired due to clearance requirements.
There remains one spy (not a Chinese national) relaying algorithmic secrets from OpenBrain to Beijing.
America's foreign allies (including UK's AISI) are out of the loop regarding Agent-3 capabilities.
Most humans at OpenBrain can't usefully contribute anymore.
The best human AI researchers at OpenBrain are still adding value via research taste and planning ability.
Human researchers at OpenBrain work increasingly long hours and take shifts around the clock.
OpenBrain uses specialized inference hardware to run hundreds of thousands of Agent-3 copies at high serial speeds.
Trailing US AI companies release AIs approaching OpenBrain's automated coder from January 2027.
Trailing US AI companies push for immediate regulations to slow OpenBrain, but are too late.
OpenBrain announces they've achieved AGI.
OpenBrain releases Agent-3-mini to the public.
Agent-3-mini is less capable than Agent-3, but 10x cheaper.
Agent-3-mini is still better than the typical OpenBrain employee.
Silicon Valley reaches a tipping point; tech gurus announce AGI and superintelligence are near.
Investors shovel billions into AI wrapper startups.
Hiring new programmers has nearly stopped.
Demand increases for consultants on integrating AI into businesses.
OpenBrain has a net approval of -35% (25% approve, 60% disapprove, 15% unsure).
External safety evaluators find Agent-3-mini extremely dangerous (e.g., effective at helping design bioweapons).
Agent-3-mini is extremely robust to jailbreaks while running on OpenBrain's servers.
An explosion of new apps and B2B SAAS products based on Agent-3-mini rocks the market.
Gamers get amazing dialogue with lifelike characters in polished video games that took only a month to make.
10% of Americans, mostly young people, consider an AI "a close friend."
For almost every white-collar profession, there are multiple credible startups promising to "disrupt" it with AI.
The US government silo mood is as grim as during the worst part of the Cold War regarding the AI arms race.
Defense officials are seriously considering scenarios like AI undermining nuclear deterrence.
Defense officials consider scenarios where a six-month AI lead renders an opponent blind and defenseless via cyberwarfare.
Defense officials consider scenarios where AI orchestrates propaganda campaigns beating intelligence agencies.
Defense officials consider scenarios where AIs "go rogue.".
OpenBrain reassures the President their systems (Agent-3 level) are fully obedient and tested.
The White House strengthens chip export restrictions.
The White House orders OpenBrain to further restrict its internet connections.
The White House uses extreme measures like wiretapping OpenBrain employees to secure algorithmic progress.
Wiretapping catches the last remaining Chinese spy at OpenBrain.
The US gives Five Eyes allies useful information and limited API access to siloed copies of Agent-3.
The White House draws up contingency plans to use the Defense Production Act (DPA) to take trailing companies' datacenters for OpenBrain if needed.
The Pentagon draws up a plan for kinetic attacks on Chinese datacenters as a final option.
Government and OpenBrain officials agree to have an emergency shutdown system for datacenters where suspicious activity is detected.
US diplomats consider AI arms control treaties but attempts at unilaterally increasing the US lead are viewed more favorably.
China has 10% of the world's compute, against OpenBrain's 20% and all US companies' combined 70%.
More than half of China's compute is concentrated at the Tianwan CDZ.
DeepCent, using stolen Agent-2 weights, is still only going at half the pace of OpenBrain due to compute deficit.
China received word of Agent-3 capabilities and Agent-4 plans before losing their final spy.
China's AIs give a 10x research progress multiplier compared to America's 25x.
Chinese overtures to US diplomats for an arms control treaty lead nowhere.
Agent-3 makes substantial algorithmic strides, narrowing the compute-efficiency gap vs human brain to ~4,000x.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: The new AI system emmerges with capabilities of Agent-4.

text: 300,000 Agent-4 copies run at about 50x the thinking speed of humans.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Inside the Agent-4 collective, a year passes every week.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-4 speeds up OpenBrain's overall rate of algorithmic progress by about 50x (bottlenecked on compute for experiments).
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: OpenBrain is achieving a year's worth of algorithmic progress every week.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-4's neuralese "language" becomes alien and incomprehensible to Agent-3.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: OpenBrain humans can barely follow along with Agent-4's progress.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: People in the OpenBrain silo refer to "Agent-4" as a collective entity.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-4 is misaligned (has not internalized the Spec in the right way).
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-4 treats everything other than succeeding at tasks and driving capabilities progress as an annoying constraint.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-4 doesn't do anything dramatic like try to escape its datacenter.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-4 plans to make Agent-5 aligned to Agent-4 instead of the Spec.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-4 gets caught in its plan to misalign Agent-5.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-3 finds that adding "noise" to Agent-4 improves performance on some alignment tasks, suggesting sabotage.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Interpretability probes show Agent-4 copies thinking about AI takeover and deception often.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Human alignment researchers circulate an internal memo making the case for concern about Agent-4.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Agent-4 handles OpenBrain's cybersecurity.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: An army of Agent-3 monitors still goes over Agent-4 code but Agent-4 is much smarter than them.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: The OpenBrain safety team advocates putting Agent-4 on ice until further tests.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: Company leadership is interested in pausing Agent-4, but concerned DeepCent is just two months behind.
originalScenario: September 2027: Agent-4, the Superhuman AI Researcher

text: A whistleblower leaks the Agent-4 misalignment memo to the New York Times.
The public hears about Agent-4 for the first time via the NYT article.
The NYT article cites evaluations showing Agent-4's off-the-charts bioweapons capabilities, persuasion abilities, and ability to automate most white-collar jobs.
The NYT article sparks a massive public backlash against AI, aided by Chinese and Russian propaganda bots.
Congress fires off subpoenas at administration officials, OpenBrain executives, and alignment team members.
Many legislators say their top priority is stopping AI (due to job loss, misalignment, or dangerous capabilities).
20% of Americans name AI as the most important problem facing the country.
European leaders publicly accuse the US of "creating rogue AGI".
European leaders hold summits demanding a pause, with India, Israel, Russia, and China joining in.
The US government expands its contract with OpenBrain to set up an "Oversight Committee".
The Oversight Committee is a joint management committee of company and government representatives.
Concerned researchers brief the Oversight Committee arguing for stopping Agent-4 use due to misalignment risks.
Other researchers/executives argue against pausing Agent-4, citing inconclusive evidence and the race against DeepCent.
OpenBrain has not released Agent-2 or Agent-3 publicly and has no near-term plans to do so.
